simulated_ratings.title: I Am Curious (Yellow) (Jag är nyfiken - en film i gult) (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The political fervor intrigued me, but the meta playfulness and explicitness felt more dated than revealing

simulated_ratings.title: 1900 (Novecento) (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweeping class politics resonated, though the sprawl dulled the impact

simulated_ratings.title: East-West (Est-ouest) (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A taut, grim portrait of entrapment that stirred me even if it leans on melodrama

simulated_ratings.title: Land and Freedom (Tierra y libertad) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Idealism and betrayal in the Spanish Civil War hit the nerve I look for

simulated_ratings.title: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal, boozy mind games I appreciated for their acting and bite

simulated_ratings.title: 56 Up (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Watching lives unfold over decades is the kind of humane inquiry I savor

simulated_ratings.title: Grapes of Wrath, The (1940)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Plainspoken, compassionate social drama that still rings true

simulated_ratings.title: Streetcar Named Desire, A (1951)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Raw psychology and tension kept me riveted

simulated_ratings.title: Judgment at Nuremberg (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moral rigor and testimony left me shaken and reflective

simulated_ratings.title: Seven Up! (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A fascinating seed of the project, engaging if not yet as profound as later entries

simulated_ratings.title: Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crime-story affectations felt derivative and left me cold

simulated_ratings.title: Mondays in the Sun (Lunes al sol, Los) (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, unvarnished portrait of working-class drift that moved me

simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp, cynical look at campaigning that scratched my political itch

simulated_ratings.title: After the Wedding (Efter brylluppet) (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Well-acted and affecting, if a bit engineered

simulated_ratings.title: Gone with the Wind (1939)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grand and watchable, but the melodrama and gloss keep me at a distance

simulated_ratings.title: Woman in the Dunes (Suna no onna) (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic, existential dread that burrowed under my skin

simulated_ratings.title: Inherit the Wind (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intelligent courtroom fireworks that still resonate

simulated_ratings.title: Eighth Day, The (Huitième jour, Le) (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm-hearted but it tipped into sentiment for me

simulated_ratings.title: Deer Hunter, The (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Searing and harrowing, despite some bloat

simulated_ratings.title: East of Eden (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A solid family drama with moments that sting, though uneven

simulated_ratings.title: Ali: Fear Eats the Soul (Angst essen Seele auf) (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly devastating and compassionate social critique

simulated_ratings.title: Lives of Others, The (Das leben der Anderen) (2006)

simulated_ratings.title: Little White Lies (Les petits mouchoirs) (2010)

simulated_ratings.title: Old Man and the Sea, The (1958)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spare and dignified, if somewhat austere

simulated_ratings.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A lush, melancholic crime epic that lingered with me

simulated_ratings.title: Rome, Open City (a.k.a. Open City) (Roma, città aperta) (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A stark resistance tale whose urgency still hits hard

recommended_movies: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson (2008)
Incredibly True Adventure of Two Girls in Love, The (1995)

simulated_ratings.title: Across the Universe (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The anti-war spirit is welcome, but the jukebox psychedelia felt more gimmick than illuminating.

simulated_ratings.title: Bringing Out the Dead (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bruising, haunted portrait of burnout and guilt that gripped me.

simulated_ratings.title: Godfather: Part II, The (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A morally rich crime chronicle whose cold, inexorable power I find riveting.

simulated_ratings.title: Waking Life (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Provocative in stretches, but the free-floating philosophizing often felt like wheel-spinning.

simulated_ratings.title: The Rider (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, compassionate and unvarnished, it hit the working-class vein I respond to.

simulated_ratings.title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Energetic and entertaining, if a bit too enamored of its subject.
Raw and earnest—more catharsis than comedy—and I respected it.

simulated_ratings.title: He Got Game (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A flawed but affecting father–son drama with morally knotty edges.

simulated_ratings.title: The Light Between Oceans (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsomely mounted, but the engineered melodrama kept me at a distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Malcolm X (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Incisive, stirring, and morally alive in a way that stayed with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Wag the Dog (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp, cynical satire that neatly scratches my political itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Diabolique (Les diaboliques) (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut, unnerving suspense with a nasty moral kick I admire.

simulated_ratings.title: Incredibly True Adventure of Two Girls in Love, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet and sincere, though slight and a touch schematic.

simulated_ratings.title: Godfather, The (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A dark, absorbing saga of power and rot that still compels me.

simulated_ratings.title: Two Women (Ciociara, La) (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A stark, compassionate view of wartime brutality that resonated.

simulated_ratings.title: Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Well-meaning but manipulative, its grief feels pushed rather than earned.

simulated_ratings.title: Duets (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Amiable road whimsy, pleasant enough but insubstantial for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Bright Star (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lovely and restrained, yet the romance stayed a bit remote for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Do the Right Thing (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Electric, humane, and politically bracing—this is the kind of heat I value.

simulated_ratings.title: Chinese Take-Out (Chinese Take-Away) (Un cuento chino) (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gently offbeat and likable, more a smile than a deep bruise.

simulated_ratings.title: Boyhood (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The passage of time moved me even as the individual scenes felt uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: Inglorious Bastards (Quel maledetto treno blindato) (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Serviceable pulp adventure that skims past the complexity I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: White Ribbon, The (Das weiße Band) (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Chilling, austere moral inquiry that lingered long after.

simulated_ratings.title: Spanish Prisoner, The (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever and coolly constructed, intriguing if somewhat mechanical.

simulated_ratings.title: Exterminating Angel, The (Ángel exterminador, El) (1962)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A wickedly sharp social trap—surreal, funny, and incisive.

simulated_ratings.title: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A meticulous, quietly gripping study in paranoia and institutional rot.

simulated_ratings.title: Grandmaster, The (Yi dai zong shi) (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous and elegiac, more mood and history than emotional wallop for me.

recommended_movies: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)
Merchant of Four Seasons, The (Händler der vier Jahreszeiten) (1972)

simulated_ratings.title: Drop Dead Gorgeous (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A mean, sharp small-town satire that scratched my cynical itch even if it’s a bit broad.

simulated_ratings.title: Last Exorcism, The (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The faux-doc skepticism and moral angle intrigued me more than the horror payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: Fountain, The (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grand spiritual romanticism left me admiring the ambition more than feeling anything.

simulated_ratings.title: Paranormal Activity 2 (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Some effective dread, but the mechanical jump-scare routine wears thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Hug Me I'm Scared 5 (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cleverly unsettling media satire wrapped in kid-show nightmares—I appreciated the bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Dancer in the Dark (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A punishing, compassionate social tragedy that moved me even as the manipulation shows.

simulated_ratings.title: It (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Solid coming-of-age spooks with heart, albeit wrapped in glossy, safe nostalgia.

simulated_ratings.title: Bad Taste (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goopy splatter goofing that’s more juvenile romp than anything I care about.

simulated_ratings.title: The Endless (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Low-budget, thoughtful sci‑fi dread with ideas and atmosphere I respond to.

simulated_ratings.title: Nowhere (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Style-drunk Gen‑X chaos whose empty provocation mostly left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Elvis (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Energetic and watchable, but the razzle-dazzle undercuts the human and political edges I wanted.

simulated_ratings.title: Mama (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gothic lullaby with some mood, but its engineered sentiment kept me at a remove.

simulated_ratings.title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober, morally knotty blockbuster warfare that hit the vein I value.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Hug Me I'm Scared 6 (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly funny meta-horror that pushes its conceit to a satisfying, eerie place.

simulated_ratings.title: Infernal (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Derivative, threadbare possession beats with little to chew on.

simulated_ratings.title: Give 'em Hell, Malone (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pulp affectations without the moral weight or novelty to hook me.

simulated_ratings.title: Inside (À l'intérieur) (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ferocious and effective, though its extremity edges toward blunt shock over substance.

simulated_ratings.title: Cutthroat Island (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Big, empty swashbuckling that sails on gloss more than grit or character.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K.: Shameless (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Candid, caustic hour with laughs, if not much lasting substance.

simulated_ratings.title: Chinoise, La (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ideological playhouse that’s stimulating in pockets but more didactic than revealing.

simulated_ratings.title: Pride and Prejudice (1940)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Witty and brisk

simulated_ratings.title: Love Letter, The (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pleasant, slight small‑town whimsy that never cut deep for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Mother! (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An audacious, scathing allegory whose feverish moral anger worked for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Absentia (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, grief-soaked creepiness with an ominous undertow I admired.

simulated_ratings.title: Pink Flamingos (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Transgressive trash that reads more as empty provocation than meaningful satire to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Grace of My Heart (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, humane music-world chronicle—uneven, yet affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: Merchant of Four Seasons, The (Händler der vier Jahreszeiten) (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, compassionate working‑class tragedy that devastated me.

simulated_ratings.title: Serial Mom (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A cheeky suburban skewering that amused me more than it engaged me.

simulated_ratings.title: Dancer, Texas Pop. 81 (1998)

simulated_ratings.title: Tom Jones (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Randy romp amused me in spots, but the broad mugging kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Clear-eyed, necessary context that sharpened my sense of how representation shapes lives.

simulated_ratings.title: Life and Death of Colonel Blimp, The (1943)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A humane, generous chronicle of friendship and changing codes that moved me deeply.

simulated_ratings.title: Cold Comfort Farm (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A breezy, witty tidy-up that’s pleasant more than piercing for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive and heartfelt, though the hyperactive multiverse busyness blunts its moral sting for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Tank Girl (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Anarchic energy and politics are there, but the loud, scattershot goofing wears thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Roma (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly devastating, compassionate portraiture that lingered without straining for effect.

simulated_ratings.feeling: The fascist gloss underscores the rot

simulated_ratings.title: The Wailing (2016)

simulated_ratings.title: 7 Plus Seven (1970)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The project deepens

simulated_ratings.title: Comfort of Strangers, The (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Seductive menace and moral rot intrigued me more than the payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: Hamlet (1964)

simulated_ratings.title: Panic in the Streets (1950)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense civic noir where procedure and stakes give the pulp real weight.

simulated_ratings.title: Sunshine Boys, The (1975)

simulated_ratings.title: Bob Roberts (1992)

simulated_ratings.title: Arizona Dream (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dreamy whimsy with flashes of feeling, but the meander undercuts me.

simulated_ratings.title: Safe (1995)
